Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Computer Architectures for 2020 and Beyond

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER project fosters international collaboration in an area of emerging (nano) technology, the design of novel neuromorphic cellular computing architectures. Led by members of a group at the Notre Dame University, the joint work will engage partners at Arizona State University and three European institutions, the Technical University Munich in Germany, the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, and Spain's Seville University. Each of the five locations currently has strong research activities on various aspects of the topic covered by the collaboration, e.g., hybrid computer architectures, emerging processing, and sensing and enabling integration technologies. All have a distinguished history of ongoing research with support from funding sources in their respective countries. Together, the researchers intend to lay the groundwork for a radically different approach to information processing that is based on brain-inspired spatial-temporal behavior in large-scale, cellular arrays of nanoelectronic processing elements. Specifically, their goal is to identify the computational building blocks for future computing systems. This collaboration will further enable the capacities of these geographically diverse groups to facilitate student exchanges, brainstorming sessions - both physical and virtual - and short exchange visits by junior researchers. Conferences, workshops, summer schools, virtual classrooms to leverage the complementary expertise of various participating centers will be organized, and dissemination of research results and educational products will be undertaken cooperatively by the group.

Thus, the broader impact of the project should be significant, especially for the participating U.S. students and junior researchers, first by gaining early career, high level technical experience abroad, some of which is not readily available in the U.S., and secondly, by exposing them to a team-focused research environment in differing disciplinary and cultural contexts. It is also noteworthy that this particular project enjoys the benefits of access to complementary expertise at highly visible research centers for societal impacts of (nano) technology, e.g., the NSF-funded Center for Nanotechnology in Society, at Arizona State University, and the Munich Center for Technology in Society, at the Carl von Linde Akademie in Munich. Such interaction is expected to greatly enhance the societal and educational value of the overall collaborative effort. This EAGER project is co-funded by the NSF's Office of International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This international collaborative EAGER project involved US partners at the University of Notre Dame and at Arizona State University, and international partners at the Technical University Munich, Germany, the Pazmany University in Budapest, Hungary, and the University of Seville. Spain. This project provided an international collaborative component of existing programs, including NSF-funded programs, and was based on long-term collaborations between the international team members, both for research and education.

The main goal of this EAGER project was to lay the groundwork for a radically different approach to information processing that is based on brain-inspired spatial-temporal behavior in large-scale, cellular arrays of nanoelectronic processing elements.  Information processing no longer will be based on elementary Boolean logic functions in von Neumann architectures, but on interacting waves in media that support such spatio-temporal excitations.  Specifically, we investigated information processing based on spin waves, inspired by earlier work on optical computing. Because of the short wavelength of spin waves, compared to electromagnetic waves in the optical regime, such systems promise a chip-scale realization of lab-bench-scale optical setups.  Such systems also promise low power and ready integration with conventional electronics. As a specific demonstration of this concept, we proposed a chip-scale device that ?computes? the spectral components of a microwave signal.

This international collaboration was planned synergistically with other existing research projects of the partner institutions, such as ?NEB: Physics-Inspired Non-Boolean Computation based on Spatial-Temporal Wave Excitations? (funded by NSF and SRC-NRI), ?Optically-Inspired Computing with Spin Waves? (funded by a gift from Intel Corp.), ?Unconventional Processing of Signals for Intelligent Data Exploitation (UPSIDE)? (funded by DARPA), ?IRES: U.S.-Hungary Research Experience for Students on Non-Boolean Computer Architectures? (funded by NSF), ?RET Site: Unconventional Computing at the University of Notre Dame (UC@UND)? (funded by NSF), and ?SpecEES: Chip-Scale Millimeter- Wave Spectrum / Signal Analyzer Using Spin-Wave Diffraction and Interference? (funded by NSF).

In addition to the research portion, this project also included a societal-impact component, which involved a collaboration between the John J. Reilly Center for Science Technology and Values at the University of Notre Dame, the Center for Nanotechnology and Society at Arizona State University, and the Munich Center for Technology in Society at the Technical University Munich. A series of workshops was organized with themes of ?System Integration? (Munich, Germany, 26-28 May 2014), ?Sensor Technologies & the Human Experience? (Munich, Germany, 21-22 July 2015), and ?Internet of Things: sustainability and energy awareness? (Bolzano / Bozen, Italy, 10-11 July 2017).

Intellectual Merit:  This project aimed to lay the groundwork for a radically different approach to information processing that is based on brain-inspired spatial-temporal behavior in large-scale, cellular arrays of nanoelectronic processing elements.  Computation no longer is based on elementary Boolean logic functions and von Neumann architectures, but on wave-like spatial-temporal activity. Specifically, our research identified spin-wave-based computational building blocks for future computing systems, along with the appropriate circuits and architectures. 

Broader Impacts: Our work has potential to impact the way information processing is done in future information-processing systems, and how circuits and computer architectures are designed for 2020 and beyond. As part of this research, graduate students and young researchers were educated and trained in this new way of thinking about how computation is done in a more brain-like fashion.  Building upon existing networks in the US and in Europe, summer schools and conferences were organized.  Moreover, the societal impacts of these new technologies were explored.
